org.threadly.concurrent

Class PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.threadly.concurrent.AbstractSubmitterExecutor
      • org.threadly.concurrent.AbstractSubmitterScheduler
        • org.threadly.concurrent.PriorityScheduledExecutor
          • org.threadly.concurrent.PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.util.concurrent.Executor, PrioritySchedulerInterface, SchedulerServiceInterface, SimpleSchedulerInterface, SubmitterExecutorInterface, SubmitterSchedulerInterface

    public class PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker
extends PriorityScheduledExecutor

    An implementation of PriorityScheduledExecutor which tracks run and usage statistics. This is designed for testing and troubleshooting. It has a little more overhead from the normal PriorityScheduledExecutor.

    It helps give insight in how long tasks are running, how well the thread pool is being utilized, as well as execution frequency.

    Since:
    1.0.0

    • Constructor Detail

      • PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker

        public PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker(int corePoolSize,
                                 int maxPoolSize,
                                 long keepAliveTimeInMs)
        Constructs a new thread pool, though no threads will be started till it accepts it's first request. This constructs a default priority of high (which makes sense for most use cases). It also defaults low priority worker wait as 500ms. It also defaults to all newly created threads being daemon threads.
        Parameters:
        corePoolSize - pool size that should be maintained
        maxPoolSize - maximum allowed thread count
        keepAliveTimeInMs - time to wait for a given thread to be idle before killing

      • PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker

        public PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker(int corePoolSize,
                                 int maxPoolSize,
                                 long keepAliveTimeInMs,
                                 boolean useDaemonThreads)
        Constructs a new thread pool, though no threads will be started till it accepts it's first request. This constructs a default priority of high (which makes sense for most use cases). It also defaults low priority worker wait as 500ms.
        Parameters:
        corePoolSize - pool size that should be maintained
        maxPoolSize - maximum allowed thread count
        keepAliveTimeInMs - time to wait for a given thread to be idle before killing
        useDaemonThreads - boolean for if newly created threads should be daemon

      • PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker

        public PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker(int corePoolSize,
                                 int maxPoolSize,
                                 long keepAliveTimeInMs,
                                 TaskPriority defaultPriority,
                                 long maxWaitForLowPriorityInMs)
        Constructs a new thread pool, though no threads will be started till it accepts it's first request. This provides the extra parameters to tune what tasks submitted without a priority will be scheduled as. As well as the maximum wait for low priority tasks. The longer low priority tasks wait for a worker, the less chance they will have to make a thread. But it also makes low priority tasks execution time less predictable.
        Parameters:
        corePoolSize - pool size that should be maintained
        maxPoolSize - maximum allowed thread count
        keepAliveTimeInMs - time to wait for a given thread to be idle before killing
        defaultPriority - priority to give tasks which do not specify it
        maxWaitForLowPriorityInMs - time low priority tasks wait for a worker

      • PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker

        public PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker(int corePoolSize,
                                 int maxPoolSize,
                                 long keepAliveTimeInMs,
                                 TaskPriority defaultPriority,
                                 long maxWaitForLowPriorityInMs,
                                 boolean useDaemonThreads)
        Constructs a new thread pool, though no threads will be started till it accepts it's first request. This provides the extra parameters to tune what tasks submitted without a priority will be scheduled as. As well as the maximum wait for low priority tasks. The longer low priority tasks wait for a worker, the less chance they will have to make a thread. But it also makes low priority tasks execution time less predictable.
        Parameters:
        corePoolSize - pool size that should be maintained
        maxPoolSize - maximum allowed thread count
        keepAliveTimeInMs - time to wait for a given thread to be idle before killing
        defaultPriority - priority to give tasks which do not specify it
        maxWaitForLowPriorityInMs - time low priority tasks wait for a worker
        useDaemonThreads - boolean for if newly created threads should be daemon

      • PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker

        public PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker(int corePoolSize,
                                 int maxPoolSize,
                                 long keepAliveTimeInMs,
                                 TaskPriority defaultPriority,
                                 long maxWaitForLowPriorityInMs,
                                 java.util.concurrent.ThreadFactory threadFactory)
        Constructs a new thread pool, though no threads will be started till it accepts it's first request. This provides the extra parameters to tune what tasks submitted without a priority will be scheduled as. As well as the maximum wait for low priority tasks. The longer low priority tasks wait for a worker, the less chance they will have to make a thread. But it also makes low priority tasks execution time less predictable.
        Parameters:
        corePoolSize - pool size that should be maintained
        maxPoolSize - maximum allowed thread count
        keepAliveTimeInMs - time to wait for a given thread to be idle before killing
        defaultPriority - priority to give tasks which do not specify it
        maxWaitForLowPriorityInMs - time low priority tasks wait for a worker
        threadFactory - thread factory for producing new threads within executor

    • Method Detail

      • resetCollectedStats

        public void resetCollectedStats()
        Clears all collected rolling statistics. These are the statistics used for averages and are limited by window sizes. This does NOT reset the total execution counts.

      • submit

        public ListenableFuture<?> submit(java.lang.Runnable task)
        Description copied from interface: SubmitterExecutorInterface
        Submit a task to run as soon as possible. There is a slight increase in load when using submit over execute. So this should only be used when the future is necessary. The future .get() method will return null once the runnable has completed.
        Specified by:
        submit in interface SubmitterExecutorInterface
        Overrides:
        submit in class AbstractSubmitterExecutor
        Parameters:
        task - runnable to be executed
        Returns:
        a future to know when the task has completed

      • getAverageTaskRunTime

        public long getAverageTaskRunTime()
        This reports the rolling average of time that tasks for this scheduler run. It only reports for tasks which have completed.
        Returns:
        average time in milliseconds tasks run

      • getMedianTaskRunTime

        public long getMedianTaskRunTime()
        This reports the median run time for tasks run by this executor. It only reports for tasks which have completed. Returns -1 if no stats have been collected yet.
        Returns:
        median time in milliseconds tasks run

      • getAvgExecutionDelay

        public long getAvgExecutionDelay()
        Gets the average delay from when the task is ready, to when it is actually executed.
        Returns:
        average delay for tasks to be executed

      • getHighPriorityAvgExecutionDelay

        public long getHighPriorityAvgExecutionDelay()
        Gets the average delay from when the task is ready, to when it is actually executed.
        Returns:
        average delay for high priority tasks to be executed

      • getLowPriorityAvgExecutionDelay

        public long getLowPriorityAvgExecutionDelay()
        Gets the average delay from when the task is ready, to when it is actually executed.
        Returns:
        average delay for low priority tasks to be executed

      • getHighPriorityMedianExecutionDelay

        public long getHighPriorityMedianExecutionDelay()
        Gets the median delay from when the task is ready, to when it is actually executed. Returns -1 if no stats have been collected yet.
        Returns:
        median delay for high priority tasks to be executed

      • getLowPriorityMedianExecutionDelay

        public long getLowPriorityMedianExecutionDelay()
        Gets the median delay from when the task is ready, to when it is actually executed. Returns -1 if no stats have been collected yet.
        Returns:
        median delay for low priority tasks to be executed

      • getHighPriorityExecutionDelays

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Long> getHighPriorityExecutionDelays()
        Call to get a list of all currently recorded times for execution delays. This is the window used for the rolling average for getHighPriorityAvgExecutionDelay(). This call allows for more complex statistics (ie looking for outliers, etc).
        Returns:
        list which represents execution delay samples

      • getLowPriorityExecutionDelays

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Long> getLowPriorityExecutionDelays()
        Call to get a list of all currently recorded times for execution delays. This is the window used for the rolling average for getLowPriorityAvgExecutionDelay(). This call allows for more complex statistics (ie looking for outliers, etc).
        Returns:
        list which represents execution delay samples

      • getRunTimes

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Long> getRunTimes()
        Call to get a list of all currently recorded times for execution. This is the window used for the rolling average for getAverageTaskRunTime(). This call allows for more complex statistics (ie looking for outliers, etc).
        Returns:
        the list of currently recorded run times for tasks

      • getTotalExecutionCount

        public int getTotalExecutionCount()
        Call to get the total qty of tasks this executor has handled.
        Returns:
        total qty of tasks run

      • getHighPriorityTotalExecutionCount

        public int getHighPriorityTotalExecutionCount()
        Call to get the total qty of high priority tasks this executor has handled.
        Returns:
        total qty of high priority tasks run

        public int getLowPriorityTotalExecutionCount()
        Call to get the total qty of low priority tasks this executor has handled.
        Returns:
        total qty of low priority tasks run

      • getRunnablesRunningOverTime

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Runnable> getRunnablesRunningOverTime(long timeInMs)
        Call to get any Runnable that have been running longer than a given period of time. This is particularly useful when looking for runnables that may be executing longer than expected. Cases where that happens these runnables could block the thread pool from executing additional tasks.
        Parameters:
        timeInMs - threshold of time to search for
        Returns:
        list of runnables which are, or had been running over the provided time length

      • getCallablesRunningOverTime

        public java.util.List<java.util.concurrent.Callable<?>> getCallablesRunningOverTime(long timeInMs)
        Call to get any Callable that have been running longer than a given period of time. This is particularly useful when looking for callables that may be executing longer than expected. Cases where that happens these callables could block the thread pool from executing additional tasks.
        Parameters:
        timeInMs - threshold of time to search for
        Returns:
        list of callables which are, or had been running over the provided time length

      • getQtyRunningOverTime

        public int getQtyRunningOverTime(long timeInMs)
        Call to return the number of callables and/or runnables which have been running longer than the provided amount of time in milliseconds.
        Parameters:
        timeInMs - threshold of time to search for execution
        Returns:
        total qty of runnables and callables which have or are running longer than the provided time length

      • getCurrentRunningCount

        public int getCurrentRunningCount()
        Description copied from class: PriorityScheduledExecutor
        Call to check how many tasks are currently being executed in this thread pool.
        Overrides:
        getCurrentRunningCount in class PriorityScheduledExecutor
        Returns:
        current number of running tasks

      • getThreadAvailablePercent

        public double getThreadAvailablePercent()
        Call to see how frequently tasks are able to immediately get a thread to execute on (and NOT having to create one). Returns -1 if no statistics have been recorded yet.
        Returns:
        percent of time that threads are able to be reused

      • getHighPriorityThreadAvailablePercent

        public double getHighPriorityThreadAvailablePercent()
        Call to see how frequently high priority tasks are able to immediately get a thread to execute on (and NOT having to create one). Returns -1 if no statistics for high priority tasks have been recorded yet.
        Returns:
        percent of time that threads are able to be reused for high priority tasks

      • getLowPriorityThreadAvailablePercent

        public double getLowPriorityThreadAvailablePercent()
        Call to see how frequently low priority tasks are able to get a thread within the max wait time for low priority tasks (and NOT having to create one). Returns -1 if no statistics for high priority tasks have been recorded yet.
        Returns:
        percent of time that threads are able to be reused for low priority tasks
